title: Faroe Islands part-timers 'riding wave' for World Cup dream
summary: The Faroe Islands could still qualify for their first World Cup with one qualification game remaining. BBC Sport looks at the impossible mission and dreams of a team full of part-timers.

title: 'I got his shirt' - Carragher on Malta & Lewandowski
summary: Not many League One defenders have played against one of the world's best strikers, but James Carragher - son of ex-England international Jamie - has the shirt to prove it.

title: Church told me I was possessed by demons aged 12 - Benn
summary: Conor Benn tells BBC Sport about growing up in an "extreme" Christian school, being told he was "demon-possessed" and how he had to rebuild a relationship with his father Nigel.

title: I think about diabetes 'every five minutes' - Slade
summary: England international Henry Slade tells BBC Sport how he manages his type 1 diabetes as a top rugby player.

title: OpenAI is piloting group conversations in ChatGPT

title: This flu season looks grim as H3N2 emerges with mutations
summary: UK facing one of worst flu seasons in historyâ€”and the US is next.
body: Health officials in the United Kingdom are warning that this yearâ€™s flu season for the Northern Hemisphere is looking like it will be particularly roughâ€”and the US is not prepared. The bleak outlook is driven by a new strain of H3N2, which emerged over the summer (at the end of the Southern Hemisphereâ€™s season) sporting several mutations. Those changes are not enough to spark the direst of circumstancesâ€”a deadly pandemicâ€”but they could help the virus dodge immune responses, resulting in an outsized number of severe illnesses that could put a significant strain on hospitals and clinics. In the UK, the virus has taken off. The regionâ€™s flu season has started around five weeks earlier than normal and is making a swift ascent. Read full article Comments

body: The day after Google filed a lawsuit to end text scams primarily targeting Americans, the criminal network behind the phishing scams was â€œdisrupted,â€ a Google spokesperson told Ars. According to messages that the â€œringleaderâ€ of the so-called â€œLighthouse enterpriseâ€ posted on his Telegram channel, the phishing gangâ€™s cloud server was â€œblocked due to malicious complaints.â€ â€œWe will restore it as soon as possible!â€ the leader posted on the channelâ€”which Googleâ€™s lawsuit noted helps over 2,500 members coordinate phishing attacks that have resulted in losses of â€œover a billion dollars.â€ Read full article Comments

title: Are you ready for a $1,000 Steam Machine? Some analysts think you should be.
summary: Tariffs, component volatility, and Valve's tolerance for losses all lead to uncertainty.
body: If you ask random gamers what price they think Valve will charge for its newly announced Steam Machine hardware , youâ€™ll get a wide range of guesses . But if you ask the analysts who follow the game industry for a living the same questionâ€¦ well, youâ€™ll actually get the same wide range of (somewhat better-informed) guesses. At the high end of those guesses are analysts like F-Squared â€˜s Michael Futter, who expects a starting price of $799 to $899 for the entry-level 512GB Steam Machine and a whopping $1,000 to $1,100 for the 2TB version. With internal specs that Futter says â€œwill rival a PS5 and maybe even hit PS5 Pro performance,â€ we can expect a â€œhefty price tagâ€ from Valveâ€™s new console-like effort. At the same time, since Valve is â€œpositioning this as a dedicated, powerful gaming PCâ€¦ I suspect that the price will be below a similarly capable traditional desktop,â€ Futter said. DFC Intelligence analyst David Cole similarly expects the Steam Machine to start at a price â€œaround $800â€ and go up to â€œaround $1,000â€ for the 2TB model. Cole said he expects Valve will seek â€œvery low marginsâ€ or even break-even pricing on the hardware itself, which he said would probably lead to pricing â€œâ€¦

title: Tiny chips hitch a ride on immune cells to sites of inflammation
summary: Tiny chips can be powered by infrared light if they're near the brain's surface.
body: Standard brain implants use electrodes that penetrate the gray matter to stimulate and record the activity of neurons. These typically need to be put in place via a surgical procedure. To go around that need, a team of researchers led by Deblina Sarkar, an electrical engineer and MIT assistant professor, developed microscopic electronic devices hybridized with living cells. Those cells can be injected into the circulatory system with a standard syringe and will travel the bloodstream before implanting themselves in target brain areas. â€œIn the first two years of working on this technology at MIT, weâ€™ve got 35 grant proposals rejected in a row,â€ Sarkar says. â€œComments we got from the reviewers were that our idea was very impactful, but it was impossible.â€ She acknowledges that the proposal sounded like something you can find in science fiction novels. But after more than six years of research, she and her colleagues have pulled it off. Nanobot problems In 2022, when Sarkar and her colleagues gathered initial data and got some promising results with their cell-electronics hybrids, the team proposed the project for the National Institutes of Health Directorâ€™s New Innovator Award. For â€¦

title: What if the aliens come and we just canâ€™t communicate?
summary: Ars chats with particle physicist Daniel Whiteson about his new book Do Aliens Speak Physics?
body: Science fiction has long speculated about the possibility of first contact with an alien species from a distant world and how we might be able to communicate with them. But what if we simply donâ€™t have enough common ground for that to even be possible? An alien species is bound to be biologically very different, and their language will be shaped by their home environment, broader culture, and even how they perceive the universe. They might not even share the same math and physics. These and other fascinating questions are the focus of an entertaining new book, Do Aliens Speak Physics? And Other Questions About Science and the Nature of Reality . Co-author Daniel Whiteson is a particle physicist at the University of California, Irvine, who has worked on the ATLAS collaboration at CERNâ€™s Large Hadron Collider. Heâ€™s also a gifted science communicator who previously co-authored two books with cartoonist Jorge Cham of PhD Comics fame: 2018â€™s We Have No Idea and 2021â€™s Frequently Asked Questions About the Universe . (The pair also co-hosted a podcast from 2018 to 2024, Daniel and Jorge Explain the Universe .) This time around, cartoonist Andy Warner provided the illustrations, and Whiteâ€¦

summary: Almost half of US car buyers won't consider a car without Apple CarPlay.
body: Apple CarPlay, the interface that lets you cast your phone to your carâ€™s infotainment screen, may finally be coming to Teslaâ€™s electric vehicles. CarPlay is nearly a decade old at this point , and it has become so popular that almost half of car buyers have said they wonâ€™t consider a car without the feature, and the overwhelming majority of automakers have included CarPlay in their vehicles. Until now, that hasnâ€™t included Tesla. CEO Elon Musk doesnâ€™t appear to have opined on the omission, though he has frequently criticized Apple. In the past, Musk has said the goal of Tesla infotainment is to be â€œthe most amount of fun you can have in a car.â€ Tesla has regularly added puerile features like fart noises to the system, and it has also integrated video games that drivers can play while they charge. For customers who want to stream music, Tesla has instead offered Spotify, Tidal, and even Apple Music apps. Read full article Comments

title: Google will let Android power users bypass upcoming sideloading restrictions
summary: Google will preserve sideloading for power users, but it hasn't decided how that will work yet.
body: Google recently decided that the freedom afforded by Android was a bit too much and announced developer verification , a system that will require developers outside the Google Play platform to register with Google. Users and developers didnâ€™t accept Googleâ€™s rationale and have been complaining loudly. As Google begins early access testing, it has conceded that â€œexperienced usersâ€ should have an escape hatch. According to Google , online scam and malware campaigns are getting more aggressive, and thereâ€™s real harm being done in spite of the platformâ€™s sideloading scare screens. Google says itâ€™s common for scammers to use social engineering to create a false sense of urgency, prompting users to bypass Androidâ€™s built-in protections to install malicious apps. Googleâ€™s solution to this problem, as announced several months ago, is to force everyone making apps to verify their identities. Unverified apps wonâ€™t install on any Google-certified device once verification rolls out. Without this, the company claims malware creators can endlessly create new apps to scam people. However, the centralized nature of verification threatened to introduce numerous headaches into a process that used tâ€¦

title: Valve says itâ€™s still waiting for better chips to power Steam Deck 2
summary: Even a 50 percent performance-per-watt improvement wouldn't be enough, engineer says.
body: Yesterdayâ€™s announcement of new living room and VR hardware from Valve obviously has many gamers clamoring for any news of a more powerful version of the nearly 4-year-old Steam Deck. In a new interview with IGN , though, Valve Software Engineer Pierre-Loup Griffais says that portable gaming silicon still hasnâ€™t advanced enough to justify brand-new benchmark hardware. â€œThe thing weâ€™re making sure of is that itâ€™s a worthwhile enough performance upgrade [for a Steam Deck 2] to make sense as a standalone product,â€ Griffais told IGN. â€œWeâ€™re not interested in getting to a point where itâ€™s 20 or 30 or even 50 percent more performance at the same battery life. We want something a little bit more demarcated than that.â€ â€œSo weâ€™ve been working back from silicon advancements and architectural improvements, and I think we have a pretty good idea of what the next version of Steam Deck is going to be, but right now thereâ€™s no offerings in that landscape, in the SoC [System on a Chip] landscape, that we think would truly be a next-gen performance Steam Deck,â€ Griffais continued. title: Tracking the winds that have turned Mars into a planet of dust
summary: Tracking winds across Mars' surface and their association with dust storms.
body: Mars is cold, parched, and extremely dusty. Powerful gusts of wind kick up literal tons of reddish dust that often takes the form of whorls known as dust devils. These winds also shroud the planet in dust by lifting material from the surface and blowing it into the atmosphere (what little Mars has left of an atmosphere), sometimes creating dust storms that rage for days. Researcher Valentin Bickel wanted to know just how intense winds can be on the red planet. Using data obtained by the Mars camera CaSSIS (Color and Stereo Surface Imaging System), the ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter , and stereo camera HRSC (High Resolution Stereo Camera) on board ESA orbiter Mars Express, he and his team used deep learning to analyze stereo images that were taken seconds apart at the same location. These images can track the motion of dust devils, and the researchers use them to infer how the winds behind the dust devils move and lift dust from the surface. That dust goes on to have a big influence on the Martian weather. Bickel, of the Center for Space and Habitability at the University of Bern, noticed that the tumultuous Martian winds are even faster than previous observations had made them out to bâ€¦

title: What would a â€œsimplifiedâ€ Starship plan for the Moon actually look like?
summary: The problem is that it may be difficult to find options that both NASA and SpaceX like.
body: In what will likely be his most consequential act as NASAâ€™s interim leader, Sean Duffy said last month that the space agency was â€œopening upâ€ its competition to develop a lunar lander that will put humans on the surface of the Moon. As part of this move, Duffy asked NASAâ€™s current lunar lander contractors, SpaceX and Blue Origin, for more nimble plans. Neither has specified those plans publicly, but a recent update from SpaceX referenced a â€œsimplifiedâ€ version of the Starship system itâ€™s building to help NASA return humans to the Moon. â€œSince the contract was awarded, we have been consistently responsive to NASA as requirements for Artemis III have changed and have shared ideas on how to simplify the mission to align with national priorities,â€ the company said. â€œIn response to the latest calls, weâ€™ve shared and are formally assessing a simplified mission architecture and concept of operations that we believe will result in a faster return to the Moon while simultaneously improving crew safety.â€ Read full article Comments

title: OpenAI walks a tricky tightrope with GPT-5.1â€™s eight new personalities
summary: New controls attempt to please critics on both sides with a balance between bland and habit-forming.
body: On Wednesday, OpenAI released GPT-5.1 Instant and GPT-5.1 Thinking, two updated versions of its flagship AI models now available in ChatGPT. The company is wrapping the models in the language of anthropomorphism, claiming that theyâ€™re warmer, more conversational, and better at following instructions. The release follows complaints earlier this year that its previous models were excessively cheerful and sycophantic , along with an opposing controversy among users over how OpenAI modified the default GPT-5 output style after several suicide lawsuits . The company now faces intense scrutiny from lawyers and regulators that could threaten its future operations. In that kind of environment, itâ€™s difficult to just release a new AI model, throw out a few stats, and move on like the company could even a year ago. But here are the basics: The new GPT-5.1 Instant model will serve as ChatGPTâ€™s faster default option for most tasks, while GPT-5.1 Thinking is a simulated reasoning model that attempts to handle more complex problem-solving tasks. Read full article Comments

title: With another record broken, the worldâ€™s busiest spaceport keeps getting busier
summary: It's not just the number of rocket launches, but how much stuff they're carrying into orbit.
body: CAPE CANAVERAL, Floridaâ€”Another Falcon 9 rocket fired off its launch pad here on Monday night, taking with it another 29 Starlink Internet satellites to orbit. This was the 94th orbital launch from Floridaâ€™s Space Coast so far in 2025, breaking the previous record for the most satellite launches in a calendar year from the worldâ€™s busiest spaceport. Monday nightâ€™s launch came two days after a Chinese Long March 11 rocket lifted off from an oceangoing platform on the opposite side of the world, marking humanityâ€™s 255th mission to reach orbit this year, a new annual record for global launch activity. As of Wednesday, a handful of additional missions have pushed the global figure this year to 259, putting the world on pace for around 300 orbital launches by the end of 2025. This will more than double the global tally of 135 orbital launches in 2021. Read full article Comments

title: Microsoft releases update-fixing update for update-eligible Windows 10 PCs
summary: A bug was keeping Windows 10 PCs from enrolling in Microsoft's ESU program.
body: Officially, Windows 10 died last month , a little over a decade after its initial release. But the old operating systemâ€™s enduring popularity has prompted Microsoft to promise between one and three years of Extended Security Updates (ESUs) for many Windows 10 PCs. For individuals with Windows 10 PCs, itâ€™s relatively easy to get an additional year of updates at no cost . Or at least, itâ€™s supposed to be. Bugs initially identified by Windows Latest were keeping some Windows 10 PCs from successfully enrolling in the ESU program, preventing those PCs from signing up to grab the free updates. And because each Windows 10 PC has to be manually enrolled in the program, a broken enrollment process also meant broken security updates. To fix the problems, Microsoft released an update for Windows 10 22H2 ( KB5071959 ) this week that both acknowledges and fixes an issue â€œwhere the enrollment wizard may fail during enrollment.â€ Itâ€™s being offered to all Windows 10 PCs regardless of whether theyâ€™re enrolled in the ESU program â€œas it resolves an issue that was preventing affected customers from receiving essential security updates.â€ Read full article Comments

title: Well-received big-budget Alien Earth TV series gets a second season
summary: Production will move from Thailand to London, suggesting a new setting.
body: Alien Earth will return to FX (and Disney+ and Hulu) for a second season, thanks to a new deal between Disney and series creator Noah Hawley. The new season has no air date yet, but we do know one thing about it: It will be shot in London. The first season was shot in Thailand, and most of the story took place in Southeast Asia, so the change in shooting location suggests a new setting for much of the next season. Production on season two will reportedly begin next year. For those who watched season one to its conclusion, season two probably seemed like a sure thing; the finale resolved many of the core conflicts of that first batch of episodes, but also was clearly intended to be the launching point for a new storyline in season two. Read full article Comments

title: Audi goes full minimalism for its first-ever Formula 1 livery
summary: Audi says it wants to be an F1 title contender by 2030.
body: Audi provided flights from Washington, DC, to Munich and accommodation so Ars could visit its motorsports facility and see its F1 car. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. MUNICH, Germanyâ€”Audiâ€™s long-awaited Formula 1 team gave the world its first look at what the Audi R26 will look like when it takes to the track next year. Well, sort ofâ€”the car you see here is a generic show car for the 2026 aero regulations, but the livery you see, plus the sponsorsâ€™ logos, will race next year. â€œBy entering the pinnacle of motorsport, Audi is making a clear, ambitious statement. It is the next chapter in the companyâ€™s renewal. Formula 1 will be a catalyst for the change towards a leaner, faster, and more innovative Audi,â€ said Gernot DÃ¶llner, Audiâ€™s CEO. â€œWe are not entering Formula 1 just to be there. We want to win. At the same time, we know that you donâ€™t become a top team in Formula 1 overnight. It takes time, perseverance, and tireless questioning of the status quo. By 2030, we want to fight for the World Championship title,â€ DÃ¶llner said. After the complicated liveries of cars like the R18 or Audi's Formula E program, the R26 is refreshingly simple. Credit: Jonathan Gitlin None of â€¦

title: Strongest evidence yet that the Epstein-Barr virus causes lupus
summary: Lupus has been linked to the Epstein-Barr virus â€“ which causes glandular fever, or mono â€“ before, but we now have evidence of how it can bring about the autoimmune condition

title: Quantum computing tech keeps edging forward
summary: IBM follows through on its June promises, plus more trapped ion news.
body: The end of the year is usually a busy time in the quantum computing arena, as companies often try to announce that theyâ€™ve reached major milestones before the year wraps up. This year has been no exception. And while not all of these announcements involve interesting new architectures like the one we looked at recently, theyâ€™re a good way to mark progress in the field, and they often involve the sort of smaller, incremental steps needed to push the field forward. What follows is a quick look at a handful of announcements from the past few weeks that struck us as potentially interesting. IBM follows through IBM is one of the companies announcing a brand-new architecture this year. Thatâ€™s not at all a surprise, given that the company promised to do so back in June ; this week sees the company confirming that it has built the two processors it said it would earlier in the year. These include one called Loon, which is focused on the architecture that IBM will use to host error-corrected logical qubits. Loon represents two major changes for the company: a shift to nearest-neighbor connections and the addition of long-distance connections. Read full article Comments

title: 'VAR has to rein its neck in' - how I'd change football for the fans
summary: In his BBC Sport column, former Premier League manager Tony Pulis looks at which laws he would change in football.

title: Cradle of humanity is still revealing new insights about our origins
summary: The Omo-Turkana basin in Africa is home to a treasure trove of ancient human fossils and tools that span 300,000 years â€“ today it is still yielding new discoveries about our species

title: At-home hypnosis relieves menopausal hot flushes
summary: Hot flushes could be relieved by listening to recordings that induce hypnosis from home, rather than having to venture to a clinic

title: Reinventing Football - five things fans would change
summary: BBC Sport asked football fans to rip up the rulebook and suggest one change to the game. Here are the top five talking points from thousands of replies.

title: Women have supercharged immune systems and we now know why
summary: Being born with two X chromosomes brings a host of health benefits, and recognising this could lead to personalised medical treatments for men and women

title: Static electricity can remove frost from windows using little energy
summary: High-voltage copper plates can remove up to three-quarters of frost from a surface, while using much less energy than conventional heating

title: Odds of asteroid 2024 YR4 hitting the moon may rise to 30 per cent
summary: In February, the James Webb Space Telescope will briefly be able to observe asteroid 2024 YR4, which currently has a 4 per cent chance of hitting the moon in 2032. Depending on what it sees, the odds of collision could drastically increase
